titlestmt.title: The Book of Thel Copy L : electronic edition
titlestmt.sponsor: The Library of Congress and the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill

filedesc.extent: 1 XML file; 16 JPEG (ISO/IEC 10918) files ranging in size from 50KB to 435KB
filedesc.publicationstmt: Chapel Hill: Eaves, Essick, Viscomi; Carolina Digital Library and ArchivesSeptember 2008
filedesc.updatestmt:
The William Blake Archive is pleased to announce the publication of electronic editions of Copies L and R of The Book of Thel. Copy L is in the Huntington Library and Art Gallery and Copy R is in the Mellon Collection, Yale Center for British Art.
The Book of Thel is dated 1789 by Blake on the title page, but the first plate (Thel's Motto) and the last (her descent into the netherworld) appear to have been completed and first printed in 1790, while Blake was working on The Marriage of Heaven and Hell. Copies L and R are from the first of three printings of Thel, during which Blake produced at least thirteen copies, printed in five different inks to diversify his stock. Copy L, for example, was printed in green ink, Copy R in brown ink; both are lightly finished in water colors. Copies from this press run were certainly on hand when Blake included the book in his advertisement "To the Public" of October 1793: "The Book of Thel, a Poem in Illuminated Printing. Quarto, with 6 designs, price 3s." Copies L and R join copies in the Archive from the other two printings: Copy F, printed and colored c. 1795, and Copy O, printed and colored c. 1818. They also join Copies H and J from the first printing; like Copy L, both are printed in green ink and lightly finished in water colors.
Like all the illuminated books in the Archive, the text and images of Thel Copies L and R are fully searchable and are supported by our Inote and ImageSizer applications. With the Archive's Compare feature, users can easily juxtapose multiple impressions of any plate across the different copies of this or any of the other illuminated books. New protocols for transcription, which produce improved accuracy and fuller documentation in editors' notes, have been applied to Copies L and R and to all the Thel texts previously published.
With the publication of Thel Copies L and R, the Archive now contains fully searchable and scalable electronic editions of sixty-seven copies of Blake's nineteen illuminated books in the context of full bibliographic information about each work, careful diplomatic transcriptions of all texts, detailed descriptions of all images, and extensive bibliographies. In addition to illuminated books, the Archive contains many important manuscripts and series of engravings, sketches, and water color drawings, including Blake's illustrations to Thomas Gray's Poems, water color and engraved illustrations to Dante's Divine Comedy, the large color printed drawings of 1795 and c. 1805, the Linnell and Butts sets of the Book of Job water colors and the sketchbook containing drawings for the engraved illustrations to the Book of Job, the water color illustrations to Robert Blair's The Grave, and all nine of Blake's water color series illustrating the poetry of John Milton.
As always, the William Blake Archive is a free site, imposing no access restrictions and charging no subscription fees. The site is made possible by the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, and the cooperation of the international array of libraries and museums that have generously given us permission to reproduce works from their collections in the Archive.

objdescid.origination: William Blake author, inventor, delineator, etcher, printer, colorist

imprint.publisher: William BlakeBlake is recorded as the author and printer on the title page but he is also the "publisher."
imprint.pubplace: LondonThe place of publication is not recorded in the work, but Blake lived in London or its suburb, Lambeth, during the etching of the copperplates and during the printing of this copy.

objdescid.compdate: 1789Objects 1 and 8 may have been composed at a slightly later date (late 1789 or early 1790) than the others. These same two objects were probably etched later than the others (late 1789 or early 1790).

etchednumbers.note: There are etched numbers—1-6 on Plates 3 through 8—but in Copy L the number (1) on Plate 3 and the number (4) on Plate 6 are not printed.

objinfo.pennednumbers: noneThe pencil numbers on Objects 2, 3, 5-7 are not by Blake.
objinfo.binding: loose in a folderThe leaves were removed from their nineteenth-century green morocco binding by F. Bedford in 1993. This binding has been retained.
objinfo.stabholes: originally stabbed through three holes, about 5.2 cm. from the top and 10.6 cm. and 9.7 cm. apart

provenance.name: Huntington Library, Art Collections, and Botanical Gardens
provenance.note: Probably acquired directly from Blake by Thomas Butts; Thomas Butts, Jr.; sold Sotheby's, 26 March 1852, lot 51 (£2.15s. to Francis Turner Palgrave); Frederick Locker by 1886; briefly the property of E. Dwight Church, who acquired Locker's "Rowfant Library" en bloc; the New York book dealer Dodd, Mead & Company, offered in their sale catalogue, *The Rowfant Library*, of c. 1906, item 1 ($375); the New York book dealer Dodd & Livingston by 1911; the dealer A. S. W. Rosenbach, acquired from Dodd and Livingston for $280 according to Edwin Wolf 2nd and John F. Fleming, *Rosenbach: A Biography* (Cleveland and New York: World Publishing Company, 1960) 74; sold by Rosenbach to Henry E. Huntington in May 1911 ($1000).

repository.institution: Huntington Library, Art Collections, and Botanical Gardens

desc.objtitle: THEL's Motto,, Object 1 (Bentley 1, Erdman i, Keynes i)

lg.l: Does the Eagle know what is in the pit?
Or wilt thou go ask the Mole;
Can Wisdom be put in a silver rod?
Or Love in a golden bowl?

desc.objtitle: THE BOOK of THEL, Object 2 (Bentley 2, Erdman ii, Keynes ii)

objnote.p: The number "2" bottom left, written in pencil, is not by Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A slender tree, entwined with a vine, arches protectively over the title words and major pictorial motifs. This combination of motifs and their position suggests a tombstone. Two birds and a human figure soar in the sky; seven other human forms, one winged, rest or climb among the title letters. Thel, wearing a long gown and holding a shepherd's crook, stands lower left and gazes at a nude man embracing a woman around the waist. The latter wears a gown and raises her arms. These small figures seem to emerge from the large, bowl-like flowers lower center and right. The leaves of this plant and a flower bud complete the design lower center and right. The design does not directly illustrate a scene in the text, but the figures embracing above the flowers may suggest the "raptures" (Plate 5, line 13) of the Cloud and the "fair eyed dew" (Plate 5, line 15) during their courtship.

component.illusobjdesc: A large tree, perhaps a willow or birch, arches over the title words and major pictorial motifs. This shape, with letters within, suggests the outline of a tombstone. The tree splits into several branches (perhaps bearing long, slender leaves) on the right.
A slender vine twines around the over-arching tree. Some of the vine's branches bear flowers and/or leaves.

Two open flowers and one bud bloom from the slender stems of a plant. These flowers may be the pasqueflower (anemone pulsatilla). They seem to be blown to the left by a gentle wind. The plant's large leaves bend to the ground. Three stems bearing spiky leaves, or the remnants of blossoms, or perhaps grain tassels also grow from the plant.
Vines or tendrils grow from all four letters of the word "Book" (line 2).
A vine or miniature tree arches over the figure seated and leaning against the B of the word "Book" (line 2).
Flame-like leaves spring from the first O of the word "Book" (line 2).
A flower, similar in shape to the much larger ones below, blooms from the K of the word "Book" (line 2). Two long stamens curve upwards from the flower.
Slender vines twine about the letters of "Thel" (line 4). Two form empty spirals.

Thel, wearing a gown and holding a shepherd's crook, stands in a delicate contrapposto posture and looks upon the figures and flowers on the right. Her long hair cascades down her neck, touching both shoulders; the hem of her gown curls about her feet and over the ground.

A youthful female hovers to the left of an open flower. She wears a gown (or at least a skirt) and raises both arms above her head as a nude male embraces her waist. Her legs are spread apart as though she were striding to the left. Strands of her long hair can be seen left of her right arm and perhaps right of her torso.
A nude, apparently youthful, man hovers to the left of an open flower and embraces a young woman around her waist. His legs are spread apart.

A seated human figure, perhaps reading or writing in a book or tablet, sits and leans against the vertical of the letter B in the word "Book" (line 2). The figure's left leg dangles downward; the right leg appears to be crossed over the left (?) upper leg.
A human figure, probably male, stands within the second O of "Book" (line 2). He wears a hat and holds a shepherd's crook.
A young man, apparently nude, climbs the vertical of the letter T in "Thel" (line 4). He probably turns his face upward.
A gowned young woman stands on the foot of the left vertical of the letter H in "Thel" (line 4). She raises both arms above her head and appears to be facing up.
A gowned young woman hovers above the horizontal of the letter H in "Thel" (line 4). She raises both her arms above her head.
A very small figure stands just to the right of the second vertical of the H in "Thel" (line 4).

A figure, possibly female, hovers above the letters E and L of "Thel" (line 4). Her legs extend to the left; her arms are raised horizontally. There may be a small object in her left hand. Her right leg may be bent at the knee, with the lower leg behind her. The long tail of her gown floats behind her, forming a scroll-like curl.
An angel with large wings sits on the horizontal, and leans against the vertical, of the letter L of "Thel" (line 4). The figure may be reading the book or tablet propped against his (?) knees.
A bird, wings extended, soars left of the word "of" in the title (line 3).
A bird, wings extended, soars right of the word "of" in the title (line 3).
Some of the washes in the sky suggest clouds.
The title words are integrated into the full-page design.

lg.l: THE BOOK of THEL
THE
BOOK
of
THEL
The Author & Printer Willm. Blake. 1789.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Five human figures soar around the title-word "Thel" (line 1): a nude man reaching toward a large eagle, a nude man holding a sword and shield, and a gowned woman holding a small child in her outstretched arms. Below, a nude man rests on the branch of a tree (or perhaps a tassel of grain) and looks up toward the child. Spiraling vines and stylized flowers, perhaps lilies, spring from several of the title letters. The design does not represent any specific incident in the text, but the man with shield and spear may be one of the "thousand fighting men" referred to near the end of the poem (Plate 8, line 16).

component.illusobjdesc: Two vines, each terminating in what may be lily-like flowers, spring from the lower-left termination of the T of "Thel" (line 1).
A spiral vine descends from the H of "Thel" (line 1).
A vine spirals upwards from the L of "Thel" (line 1). It terminates in what may be a flower, perhaps a lily.
A spiky form that may be a stylized lily springs from the top-left corner of the H of "Thel" (line 1).
A small vine, branching at its lower end, hovers between the feet of the T and H in "Thel" (line 1).
A small vine extends horizontally beneath the E and L of "Thel" (line 1).
Two small vines extend horizontally above the T and first vertical of the H of "Thel" (line 1).
One of the figures rests on a tree branch or, if the perspective is microscopic, a tassel of grain. Another branch arches over his head.
A nude man hovers in the air, legs spread and with his right arm reaching (or pointing with one finger) toward an eagle.
A nude male hovers in the air. He holds a sword with a spiraling blade in his right hand; a shield is apparently strapped to his left arm.
A nude man reclines on a branch or tassel of grain. He props himself up with his right arm and turns his head upward.
A gowned woman hovers in the air. Her outstretched arms hold a young child.
An infant or young child hovers in the air, supported by a woman's outstretched arms. The child's legs are spread apart and its right arm may be extended toward the woman.
A large bird, probably an eagle, soars above the title-word "Thel" (line 1). Its prominent beak is open.
Washes suggest clouds in the sky. The reddish tinting on the right hints at a sunrise or sunset.
The letters of the heading are integrated into the design.

lg.l: THEL

l.note: The etched number "1" is not printed.

lg.l: The daughters of Mne Seraphim led round their sunny flocks,
All but the youngest. she in paleness sought the secret air.
To fade away like morning beauty from her mortal day:
Down by the river of Adona her soft voice is heard:
And thus her gentle lamentation falls like morning dew.
O life of this our spring! why fades the lotus of the water?
Why fade these children of the spring? born but to smile & fall.
Ah! Thel is like a watry bow, and like a parting cloud.
Like a reflection in a glass. like shadows in the water.
Like dreams of infants. like a smile upon an infants face.
Like the doves voice, like transient day. like music in the air:
Ah! gentle may I lay me down and gentle rest my head.

And gentle sleep the sleep of death. and gentle hear the voiceAt the end of the ninth word ("gentle") in line 15, Blake first wrote "e" and then wrote "y" over it before etching the copper plate. Both letters printed in proof Copy a and possibly Copy C; Blake then removed the "e" from the copper and printed the word as "gently" in Copies K and R. He then reshaped the "y" into an "e" on the copper plate and printed the word as "gentle" in all other copies, sometimes strengthening the "e" in pen and ink.
Of him that walketh in the garden in the evening time.
The Lilly of the valley breathing in the humble grass
Answerd the lovely maid and said, I am a watry weed.
And I am very small, and love to dwell in lowly vales;
So weak the gilded butterfly scarce perches on my head
Yet I am visited from heaven and he that smiles on all.
Walks in the valley. and each morn over me spreads his hand
Saying, rejoice thou humble grass, thou new-born lilly flower.
Thou gentle maid of silent valleys. and of modest brooks:
For thou shalt be clothed in light, and fed with morning manna;
Till summers heat melts thee beside the fountains and the springs
To flourish in eternal vales: then why should Thel complain.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Thel stands beneath the arching branches of a tree, perhaps a birch or willow. She bows slightly toward the personified Lilly who, with arms folded, bows more deeply toward Thel. Both females wear long gowns, ruffled along the hems. A vine climbs lazily about the tree trunk. This vine seems to grow from the plant right of Thel. The plant behind and to the right of the Lilly is probably a lily, perhaps the St. Bernard's lily. The design illustrates the dialogue between Thel and the Lilly given in the text on this plate. The moment pictured may be their parting, when "the Lilly bowd her modest head" (line 18).

component.illusobjdesc: A tree with arching branches forms a canopy over the figures. It may be a birch or willow. Small leaves dangle from the smaller branches on the left.
A plant grows between Thel and the tree and right of the tree. Flowering, vine-like stems curl upwards from this plant.
A large lily plant, perhaps the St. Bernard's lily, blooms behind and to the right of the personified Lilly. It bears three flowering stems.

Thel, wearing a long gown with a ruffled hem, stands with her arms at her side in a slightly bowed posture, facing to the left. Her long hair falls over her shoulders. Her feet (right foot forward) are bare.
The personified Lilly bows, with arms apparently folded, toward Thel. The hem of the Lilly's gown is elaborately ruffled. She faces down and to the right.
Washes in the sky suggest clouds, including one large cloud behind Thel and the Lilly.
Reddish tinting behind the tree hints at a sunrise or sunset.

lg.l: Why should the mistress of the vales of Har, utter a sigh.
She ceasd & smild in tears, then sat down in her silver shrine.
Thel answerd, O thou little virgin of the peaceful valley.

Giving to those that cannot crave. the voiceless, the o'erfired.In Copy L, the period at the end of the line is much higher, in relation to the letters in the line, than is customary. Perhaps this is actually the upper point of a colon or semicolon in which the lower element was not etched or did not print.
Thy breath doth nourish the innocent lamb. he smells thy milky garments,
He crops thy flowers. while thou sittest smiling in his face,
Wiping his mild and meekin mouth from all contagious taints.
Thy wine doth purify the golden honey, thy perfume,
Which thou dost scatter on every little blade of grass that springs
Revives the milked cow, & tames the fire-breathing steed.
But Thel is like a faint cloud kindled at the rising sun;
I vanish from my pearly throne, and who shall find my place.
Queen of the vales the Lilly answerd, ask the tender cloud,
And it shall tell thee why it glitters in the morning sky.
And why it scatters its bright beauty thro' the humid air.
Descend O little cloud & hover before the eyes of Thel,
The Cloud descended. and the Lilly bowd her modest head:
And went to mind her numerous charge among the verdant grass.

objnote.p: The number "5" bottom left, written in pencil, is not by Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Two vines, one bearing lily-like flowers, spring from the beginning of the first line of verse (line 3).

component.illusobjdesc: Two vines, one bearing lily-like flowers, spring from the beginning of the first line of verse (line 3).

illustration.illusobjdesc: A vine or two branches grow from the end of the last line of verse (line 33).

component.illusobjdesc: A vine or two branches grow from the end of the last line of verse (line 33).

illustration.illusobjdesc: Washes just below the top of the plate suggest sky, possibly with clouds.

component.illusobjdesc: Washes just below the top of the plate suggest sky, possibly with clouds.

lg.l: O little Cloud the virgin said. I charge thee tell to me.
Why thou complainest not when in one hour thou fade away:
Then we shall seek thee but not find: ah Thel is like to thee.
I pass away. yet I complain, and no one hears my voice.
The Cloud then shew'd his golden head & his bright form emerg'd,
Hovering and glittering on the air before the face of Thel.
O virgin know'st thou not. our steeds drink of the golden springs
Where Luvah doth renew his horses: look'st thou on my youth,
And fearest thou because I vanish and am seen no more.
Nothing remains; O maid I tell thee when I pass away,
It is to tenfold life. to love. to peace and raptures holy:
Unseen descending. weigh my light wings upon balmy flowers;
And court the fair eyed dew. to take me to her shining tent;
The weeping virgin, trembling kneels before the risen sun.
Till we arise link'd in a golden band. and never part;
But walk united, bearing food to all our tender flowers
Dost thou O little Cloud? I fear that I am not like thee;
For I walk through the vales of Har, and smell the sweetest flowers;
But I feed not the little flowers: I hear the warbling birds,
But I feed not the warbling birds. they fly and seek their food;
But Thel delights in these no more because I fade away,
And all shall say, without a use this shining woman liv'd,
Or did she only live. to be at death the food of worms.
The Cloud reclind upon his airy throne and answer'd thus.
Then if thou art the food of worms. O virgin of the skies,
How great thy use. how great thy blessing; every thing that lives,
Lives not alone. nor for itself: fear not and I will call
The weak worm from its lowly bed, and thou shalt hear its voice.
Come forth worm of the silent valley, to thy pensive queen.
The helpless worm arose, and sat upon the Lillys leaf,
And the bright Cloud saild on, to find his partner in the vale.

objnote.p: The numbers "4" top right and "6" bottom left, both written in pencil, are not by Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Thel stands center right, accompanied by the personified Cloud and Worm. Her arms, raised horizontally, imitate the gesture of the cloud, a nude male (except for a slip of drapery) hovering in the air. The hem of Thel's gown seems to be ruffled by the same breeze on which the Cloud floats. The Worm, portrayed as an infant, rests in a bed formed by a lily plant. Several flowers on a single stem are pictured just to the left of the infant Worm. A tree trunk and a spiraling vine dominate the right margin. A large cloud or clouds fill the sky right and left of Thel; blue washes extending to the left margin suggest sky. The design would seem to illustrate the last two lines of verse on the previous plate and the first line of verse on this plate: "The helpless worm arose, and sat upon the Lillys leaf, / And the bright Cloud saild on, to find his partner in the vale. / . . . Then Thel astonish'd view'd the worm upon its dewy bed" (Plate 5, lines 32-33; Plate 6, line 2).

component.illusobjdesc: The trunk of a tree, perhaps a birch, is pictured along the right margin.
A vine spirals upward in front of and to the left of the tree trunk.

A large plant with spiky leaves, probably a lily, forms a bed for the infant Worm. A long vine-like tendril trails to the left. A small cluster of flowers, perhaps St. Bernard's lilies, appears left of the Worm.
A few spiky lines indicate grass or a small plant to the left of the tree.

Thel stands with arms raised horizontally, as if imitating the Cloud's gestures, and looks down at the personified Worm. The hem of her gown flutters to the left, as though blown by a breeze, but her long hair seems blown to the right. She may be striding away from the viewer and to the left. Her feet, left foot forward, are bare.

The personified Cloud hovers in the air, his arms raised horizontally and his legs apart, the left bent at the knee. He is basically nude, but a flag-like piece of drapery trails behind him. His long hair floats to the right.
The personified Worm, a nude infant boy, lies among the leaves of a lily plant. He may be looking up and to the right, towards Thel.
Washes in the sky left and right of Thel delineate one or more large clouds. Washes on the left suggest sky.

The hem of Thel's gown and the posture of the personified Cloud suggest a wind blowing from right to left. However, the position of these characters' long hair suggests a breeze in the opposite direction.

l.note: In Copy L, the etched number "4" did not print.

lg.l: Then Thel astonish'd view'd the Worm upon its dewy bed.
Art thou a Worm? image of weakness, art thou but a Worm?
I see thee like an infant wrapped in the Lillys leaf:
Ah weep not little voice, thou can'st not speak. but thou can'st weep;
Is this a Worm? I see thee lay helpless & naked: weeping,
And none to answer, none to cherish thee with mothers smiles.
The Clod of Clay heard the Worms voice, & raisd her pitying head;
She bowd over the weeping infant. and her life exhal'd
In milky fondness. then on Thel she fix'd her humble eyes.
O beauty of the vales of Har. we live not for ourselves.
Thou seest me the meanest thing, and so I am indeed;
My bosom of itself is cold. and of itself is dark,

objnote.p: The number "7" bottom left, written in pencil, is not by Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Thel squats on the ground, arms folded, and looks at the personified Worm and Clod (or "matron Clay" [line 15]). Her long hair cascades over her shoulders; the hem of her long gown billows around her. The infant Worm extends both arms and looks at the Clod, a young, nude woman lying on the ground. Right of Thel is a large plant with spiky leaves and two blossoms, one of which arches over Thel's head. Left of Thel is another plant with similar leaves but no blossoms. A number of large clouds fill the sky behind Thel, including one on the left which is dark and threatening. The design may in part illustrate lines on the previous plate: "The Clod of Clay heard the Worms voice, & raisd her pitying head; / She bow'd over the weeping infant..." (Plate 6, lines 8-9).

component.illusobjdesc: A large plant with spiky leaves grows on the right. One of its two flowers arches above Thel's head. Long stamens dangle from the blossom on the right; the blossom on the left is less open and may be only a bud. The plant may be a combination of the flowers of the Meadia or dodecatheon, the golden amaryllis, and the leaves of the St. Bernard's lily.
A large plant with spiky leaves rises to the left of Thel. This may be the colorless monotropa or corpse-plant.
Two stems grow just left of Thel's waist. Both terminate in a small, lily-like flower.

Thel squats on the ground, her arms folded over her chest and knees in a contracted position. Her long hair falls over her shoulders; the hem of her long gown cascades around her. She looks down at the personified Clod and Worm with head bowed.
The nude, infant Worm lies on the ground with legs crossed and arms extended at an angle of 135 degrees. His head is turned toward the Clod.
The personified Clod or "matron Clay" (line 15) lies on the ground. She is a nude young woman with long hair. Her right arm extends under the infant Worm, perhaps propping him up.
Large clouds dominate the sky behind Thel. The cloud on the left is dark and threatening; it suggests a storm. Reddish tints upper left and on the right hint at a sunrise or sunset.

lg.l: But he that loves the lowly, pours his oil upon my head,
And kisses me, and binds his nuptial bands around my breast.
And says; Thou mother of my children, I have loved thee.
And I have given thee a crown that none can take away
But how this is sweet maid, I know not, and I cannot know,
I ponder, and I cannot ponder; yet I live and love.
The daughter of beauty wip'd her pitying tears with her white veil,
And said. Alas! I knew not this, and therefore did I weep:
That God would love a Worm I knew, and punish the evil foot
That wilful, bruis'd its helpless form; but that he cherish'd it
With milk and oil, I never knew; and therefore did I weep.
And I complaind in the mild air, because I fade away,
And lay me down in thy cold bed, and leave my shining lot.
Queen of the vales, the matron Clay answerd; I heard thy sighs.
And all thy moans flew o'er my roof. but I have call'd them down:
Wilt thou O Queen enter my house, 'tis given thee to enter.
And to return; fear nothing. enter with thy virgin feet.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Three children ride on the back of a snake. The front-most child, apparently a girl, holds a rein in her left hand that extends to the snake's open mouth. His forked tongue is extended. Beneath the snake are a variety of vegetative forms, including vines and leaves. "The End" (line 27) is written within a hollow formed by the ground and vegetation. The design bears no direct relationship with any images or events in the text.

component.illusobjdesc: Spiky lines and the coloring suggest grass and perhaps small plants on the ground.
One large leaf rests on the ground right of "The End" (line 27). This may be an oak leaf.
Several curved and pointed forms above and left of "The End" (line 27) may be leaves.
The vegetative forms left of "The End" (line 27) and extending toward the left margin may be vines bearing small leaves.
A young girl with long hair rides the snake's back. She may be wearing a gown (note the line at her waist). She holds a single rein in her left hand and faces to the left.
A nude child or infant, probably male, rides on the snake's back. His legs are spread apart. He reaches back with his left arm to grasp the left hand of the baby behind him.
A nude infant rides the snake's back nearest the tail. He faces left and reaches up with his left arm to grasp the hand of the child to the left.
A snake carries three children on his back. His mouth is open, forked tongue extended. His tail spirals into three loops.
Washes above the snake suggest sky, possibly with clouds.
The words "The End" (line 27) appear within a hollow formed by the ground and vegetation.

lg.l: The End

illustration.illusobjdesc: A curved, horizontal line on line 18 of the text suggests a vine or branch. To the right is a bird in flight and two clusters of lines suggesting clouds.

component.illusobjdesc: A vine or branch extends horizontally on line 18 of the text.
A bird flies upward on line 18 of the text.
The two clusters of lines on line 18 of the text and near the right margin may represent two clouds.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A vine or branch with a few leaves curves above the first two words of text (line 3).

component.illusobjdesc: A vine or branch with a few leaves curves above the first two words of text (line 3).

lg.l: The eternal gates terrific porter lifted the northern bar.
Thel enter'd in & saw the secrets of the land unknown:
She saw the couches of the dead, & where the fibrous roots
Of every heart on earth infixes deep its restless twists:
A land of sorrows & of tears where never smile was seen.
She wanderd in the land of clouds thro' valleys dark, listning
Dolours & lamentations: waiting oft beside a dewy grave
She stood in silence. listning to the voices of the ground,
Till to her own grave plot she came, & there she sat down.
And heard this voice of sorrow breathed from the hollow pit -
Why cannot the Ear be closed to its own destruction?
Or the glistning Eye to the poison of a smile!
Why are Eyelids stord with arrows ready drawn,
Where a thousand fighting men in ambush lie?
Or an Eye of gifts & graces, show'ring fruits & coined
gold!
Why a Tongue impress'd with honey from every wind?
Why an Ear, a whirlpool fierce to draw creations in?
Why a Nostril wide inhaling terror trembling & affright
Why a tender curb upon the youthful burning boy!
Why a little curtain of flesh on the bed of our desire?
The Virgin started from her seat, & with a shriek.
Fled back unhinderd till she came into the vales of
Har
